column2: Soul of a Fae wrapped in the flesh of a mortal human.

A Kinain is a mortal that possesses faerie blood, but is not a full Changeling. Some Kinain are marked with unusual traits by their Faerie Blood that depend on their heritage (a descendant of a satyr is hairy and social, while a descendant of a Boggan is short and usually works with his hands).
These giants of the fae possess incredible strength and determination. Once they give their loyalty, nothing can sway them from those they have sworn to protect. Honor walks in their footsteps.

Called the underfolk by many, the sluagh are often pariahs even among other fae. Places dark and forgotten, often with a mushroom garden, attract them. Those who intrude into their inner sanctums often leave with nightmares. Just as they value secrets and mysteries, sluagh treasure their privacy, and do a great deal to foster reputations that discourage visitors.

Fear and violence spawn dreams as readily as kings or commoners, and the Redcaps are the kithain most closely tied to nightmares. They gain their name from their traditional headwear - a white cap, dyed red in their victims' blood. Though quick to anger and capable of eating literally anything, Redcaps are not always evil or even Unseelie, though Redcaps of the Seelie Court are rare and sometimes ostracized by their peers.

Satyrs are a kith sprung from dreams of revelry, lust and passion. They throw a party like no-one else, drinking, fighting and loving harder than most mortals would ever dare. They are physically adept, and like the god Pan may inflame the passions of others through music and dance, but all the reveling leaves them with little willpower to resist temptation.
The Eshu are born of the dreams of the Middle East
column3: they are wanderers and storytellers, and have no peers as navigators in the Dreaming. They are also incorrigible risktakers, unable to resist a dare or wager if they feel they might succeed, no matter the danger. These things all give them a reputation for being unreliable, but few kithain would refuse them a place at the table to hear their stories of far off lands.

column2: Boggans are born of dreams of hearth and home. If roads go ever on, the goal is always the return. They derive their greatest pleasures from work and a job well done. Honest work, good company, and a regular routine are all they need. Of all the Kithain they are known for their honesty and integrity. It is said they are as honest as the dirt under their fingernails.

Nockers are the artisans among the Kithain, able to craft the stuff of dreams into whatever they desire. Their creations are always flawed, however, and their knowledge of this curse makes them irritable and quick to anger.

A Celtic Gallian, they are most often found in Hibernia.  The Clurichaun are an endearing kith that excels at revelry while holding their own when given responsibilities. They love a good time and work hard to make sure everyone enjoys themselves.

Pranksters and comedians, Pooka are well-loved by kithain and mortal alike, but few who know them well ever trust them completely: they are incapable of telling the whole truth. Each is able to take on the form of a specific animal, most often one with a tie to human stories of mischief.
Piskies are child-like tricksters with an affinity for children and a magpie-like streak of kleptomania, though they never steal maliciously. They are one of the rarer kiths among the kithain.

Selkies are skinchanger fae, able to assume the form of a seal thanks to a chimerical sealskin. Selkies are neither sea or land creatures, but inhabit the shoreline in between. Their sealskins may have a Seeming that resembles anything from a belt to a coat. When in human shape, the selkie can always tell the location of their sealskin, and damage to the sealskin can hurt or even kill them. If a selkie's sealskin is stolen or lost, the selkie cannot spend Glamour or do any fae magic until it is recovered. Donning the sealskin and immersing themselves in water allows the selkie to change into their seal form, which resembles a normal harp seal or harbor seal. In human form, selkies have large, dark eyes and may have slightly webbed fingers and toes

The Ghille dhu are the dreams of Wales, changelings who are intimately tied to the trees and to the seasons. They are rarely, if ever, seen outside their spiritual home, and perceive the world and the turning of the wheel differently to other kithain.
The Spring and Summer Court of the Fae
The Spring and Summer Court of the Fae
The Autumn and Winter Court of the Fae

In secret, Seelie loyalists have organized themselves as a community in this province. From there it converts others, grows, and protects their own.
column3: Des fidèles seelie ont secrètement formé une communauté dans cette province. Ils y convertissent les autres personnes et protègent les leurs.
column4: In dieser Provinz haben sich Seelieisten heimlich zu einer Gemeinde organisiert. Von dort aus bekehrt diese Gemeinde andere, wird immer größer und beschützt ihre Mitglieder.
column6: Los fieles seelieistas han creado una comunidad secreta en esta provincia. De este modo convierten a otros, crecen y protegen a los suyos.

column6: Los fieles unseelieistas han creado una comunidad secreta en esta provincia. De este modo convierten a otros, crecen y protegen a los suyos.

Fuddle: Alters an existing perception in a small way, such as exchanging one loud sound for another, or faking invisibility from a cover of shadow.
Veiled Eyes: Causes an object to be ignored
column3: while not truly invisible, onlookers will not think to notice the object.

column2: Fugue: Removes a memory from a person's mind, or cause one specific moment to stand out and occlude others.
Haunted Heart: Evoke some sort of phantom emotion within a subject, by reawakening an emotion felt in the past.
Captive Heart: Use emotion as a controlling force, causing a person to believe things about himself that may never have been true.
Gimmix: Produces a simple telekinetic movement, allowing an object to be moved at range, but not finely manipulated.
Ensnare: Moves an object too heavy to be moved by Gimmix, or a flexible object to attempt to bind an individual.
Effigy: Produces a carbon copy of a given item, though traits of that item below the surface fail to be copied.
Mooch: An object that is visible to the caster is immediately transferred into the user's possession.
Phantom Shadows: Produces a temporary chimera that appears in the form of what the user desires it to, with some limitation.
Omen: The most basic form of prophecy, this cantrip grants a momentary flash of insight about an object's ultimate fate.
Fair Is Foul and Foul is Fair: Meddles in the affairs of fate slightly, granting a little good luck to an ally, or a tiny bit of bad luck to the enemy.
Tattletale: See the world from the perspective of an item that the user has encountered in the past, or knows the True Name of.
Augury: Determines an event that will occur in the future
column3: no matter what happens, that event will occur, though the truth behind how it happens may be terribly unexpected.

column2: Fate Fire: A strange and complicated cantrip, this speeds up the ravages of karma, causing whatever is coming to someone, good or bad, to catch up to them much faster than expected.
Hopscotch: Produce an impossible leap, either up or down, and suffer no damage from the resulting collision.
Quicksilver: Allows an object to move at an incredibly fast speed.
Portal Passage: Creates a temporary opening through any barrier, allowing it to be moved through.
Wind Runner: Allows a target to fly, taking to the sky as if they had wings.
Flicker Flash: Instantly disappear, and reappear somewhere else in the world, or in the Dreaming (though, it is usually unwise to use it to cross between the two).
Protocol: Brings a magically ensured Court into session, preventing commoners from disrupting the proceedings.
Dictum: Specifies a request to the subject of the cantrip, which they must fulfill to the best of their ability, unless it is too dangerous.
Grandeur: Take on a mantle of pure beauty and grace, making it nearly impossible for others to try to contradict your desires.
Weaver Ward: Block off a doorway or narrow passage, making it impossible for a specified group of objects to pass through.
Geas or Ban: Produces an Oath, either requiring a person to fulfill an action (Geas), or abstain from doing a certain action (Ban)
column3: breakers of this Oath will suffer some curse as a result.

column2: True Friend: A well known confidant, a buddy.
Personal Contact: You must know this person's name, have had conversations, etc.
Familiar Face: You must recognize his/her face.
Complete Stranger: You don't need to know anything, but they cannot be hostile toward you.
Dire Enemy: You can be opposed to someone, hate them, or otherwise be in conflict.
Lofty Noble: Anyone with the Title background.
Manifold Chimera: Chimera & chimerical items of any sort.
Elusive Gallain: All fae beings not covered above - Nunnehi, inanimae, etc.
Dweomer of Glamour: Anything composed of Glamour - Cantrips, treasures, etc.
Ornate Garb: Objects commonly worn, including tattoos.
Crafted Tool: An item having no moving parts.
Mechanical Device: Any item with moving parts but that does not require fuel.
Complex Machine: An item with movablecomponents that anyone can understand
Arcane Artifact: Any item not covered, usually with complex components.
Raw Material: Unliving, organic materials: wood, rope, paper, etc.
Verdant Forest: Living, organic plant material.
Natural Phenomena: Weather, volcanic eruptions, geothermal reactions, etc.
Base Element: Natural elements in pure form, or earth, air, water, fire.
Guest Room: Up to 50 square feet.
Ground Floor: Up to 100 square feet.
Just a Moment: Up to 30 seconds.
One Mighty Minute: Up to 1 minute.
What Was I Saying? Up to 1 week
A rusty spoon.  In the hands of the Fae, it becomes a powerful sword.
To the ignorant mortals, it is a book of gibberish.  To the Fae, it contains the lore of mystical cantrips.
